summary: This is a draft email from an Assistant U.S. Attorney to defense attorneys Roy Black and Jay, raising two issues regarding the Jeffrey Epstein case: Epstein's attempt to obtain work release contrary to the Non-Prosecution Agreement, and an ethics complaint filed against the prosecutors by Stuart Mermelstein regarding victim notification letters.

persons.name: Roy Black
persons.context: Recipient of the draft email, addressed regarding issues with the Epstein case, specifically Epstein's potential work release request and an ethics complaint.

persons.name: Jay
persons.context: Recipient of the draft email alongside Roy Black, addressed regarding the Epstein case issues.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the case; the email discusses his attempt to obtain work release during his incarceration, which is alleged to contradict the Non-Prosecution Agreement and prior assurances.

persons.name: Jack Goldberger
persons.context: Mentioned as having confirmed to the email's author the weekend before Epstein's guilty plea that Epstein would be in custody and would not seek work release during his 18-month incarceration.

persons.name: Stuart Mermelstein
persons.context: Filed an Ethics Complaint with the Florida Bar against the prosecutors, asserting that letters to victims advising them of their rights under the Non-Prosecution Agreement violated Florida Bar Rules.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was attempting to obtain work release during his 18-month incarceration, which the prosecution viewed as contrary to the terms and spirit of the Non-Prosecution Agreement.
Prior to Epstein's guilty plea, attorney Jack Goldberger assured the prosecutor that Epstein would be in custody and would not seek work release during his term.
Attorney Stuart Mermelstein filed an Ethics Complaint with the Florida Bar against the prosecutors, challenging the victim notification letters sent under the Non-Prosecution Agreement.
The prosecution anticipated needing to disclose the entire Non-Prosecution Agreement to the Florida Bar's Ethics Counsel in response to Mermelstein's complaint.
